history.content:
I've noticed that it depends by company. Some have a specific handshake application (Juniper & Weight Watchers last year had this), some will just choose from their pool of applicants from the company website (bigger companies generally like Microsoft, Adobe, etc), and some will choose after career fairs & networking events (Cisco did this last year).

Not an official answer just something I've observed.

children.subject: I'd say it depends. It's hard to tell which ones are useful or not. Some of them have given me same-day or same-week on-site interviews. Others I've never even heard back from. I just go to all of them just for the chance they do contact me haha.
How useful are attending tech talks and info sessions? I've been to a couple so far and only one of them accepted resumes.

history.content: I noticed on Handshake that there are applications for on-campus interviews and I was wondering how this works. Many of the applications lead to the company websites where you can submit applications. To be considered for on-campus interviews, do you have to apply on Handshake somehow or do you submit your applications to the company website and they'll reach out if they want to interview you on campus?
history.subject: Handshake on-campus interview
